abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Niemann-Pick type C1 disease (NPC1 [OMIM 257220]) is a rare and severe autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by a multitude of neurovisceral clinical manifestations and a fatal outcome with no effective treatment to date. Aiming to gain insights into the genetic aspects of the disease, clinical, genetic, and biomarker PPCS data from 602 patients referred from 47 countries and diagnosed with NPC1 in our laboratory were analyzed. Patients’ clinical data were dissected using Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) terms, and genotype–phenotype analysis was performed. The median age at diagnosis was 10.6 years (range 0–64.5 years), with 287 unique pathogenic/likely pathogenic (P/LP) variants identified, expanding <jats:italic>NPC1</jats:italic> allelic heterogeneity. Importantly, 73 P/LP variants were previously unpublished. The most frequent variants detected were: c.3019C > G, p.(P1007A), c.3104C > T, p.(A1035V), and c.2861C > T, p.(S954L). Loss of function (LoF) variants were significantly associated with earlier age at diagnosis, highly increased biomarker levels, and a visceral phenotype (abnormal abdomen and liver morphology). On the other hand, the variants p.(P1007A) and p.(S954L) were significantly associated with later age at diagnosis (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> < 0.001) and mildly elevated biomarker levels (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> ≤ 0.002), consistent with the juvenile/adult form of NPC1. In addition, p.(I1061T), p.(S954L), and p.(A1035V) were associated with abnormality of eye movements (vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> ≤ 0.05). We describe the largest and most heterogenous cohort of NPC1 patients published to date. Our results suggest that besides its utility in variant classification, the biomarker PPCS might serve to indicate disease severity/progression. In addition, we establish new genotype–phenotype relationships for “frequent” <jats:italic>NPC1</jats:italic> variants.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: PGM, LMP, CP, SS, DV, LSA, CJ, HH, CCYL, AL, GTM, SO, M-II, SF, T-MS, NV, CC, KKK, JPB, TB, PB, and AB-A are employees of Centogene GmbH.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The research was carried out in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. The current project was conducted within a diagnostic setting and in the second step, utilized deidentified data and samples—thus not requiring IRB approval in our jurisdiction. Informed consent was obtained from the referring physicians, patients, and/or their parents or legal guardians, including publication of anonymized individual details. The informed consent form is available in English and several other languages at: ExternalRef removed.
